# Notation Rules and Tables {#sec-notation}

Consistent mathematical notation is essential for clarity in spacecraft dynamics and control. This section establishes comprehensive notation rules used throughout the manuscript.

## Notation Rules {#sec-notation-rules}

### Vector Notation

::: {#def-vector-notation}
## Vector Representation

- **Free 3D vectors** are denoted with arrow symbols: $\vec{v}$
- **Coordinate vectors** are written in **bold**: $\mathbf{v}$
- **Reference frame subscript** may be appended: $\mathbf{v}_i$ (vector in frame $i$)
:::

**Example**:
$$
\vec{v} \quad \text{(geometric vector)} \quad \longrightarrow \quad \mathbf{v}_{\mathcal{B}} = \begin{bmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \\ v_3 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{(coordinates in frame } \mathcal{B}\text{)}
$$

### Column Vector Convention

::: {.callout-important}
## Default Orientation

Coordinate vectors are **column vectors** by default. The non-standard inline notation:

$$\mathbf{v} = [v_1, v_2, v_3]$$

represents a **column** 3D vector, equivalent to:

$$\mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \\ v_3 \end{bmatrix}$$
:::

### Quaternion Notation

Quaternions can be represented in two equivalent forms:

**Matrix form**:
$$
\mathbf{q} = \begin{bmatrix} q_0 \\ \mathbf{q}_v \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} q_0 \\ q_1 \\ q_2 \\ q_3 \end{bmatrix}
$$ {#eq-quat-notation-matrix}

**Inline notation**:
$$
\mathbf{q} = [q_0, \mathbf{q}_v] = [q_0, q_1, q_2, q_3]
$$ {#eq-quat-notation-inline}

where:
- $q_0$: scalar part
- $\mathbf{q}_v = [q_1, q_2, q_3]^T$: vector part

### Variable Processing Marks

Different processing stages of variables are distinguished by marks:

| Mark | Symbol | Meaning | Mathematical Notation | Description |
|------|--------|---------|---------------------|-------------|
| None | - | True variable | $y(t)$ | Actual physical quantity |
| Overbar | ¯ | Measured variable | $\bar{y}(t)$ | Sensor measurement |
| Tilde | ~ | Generic error | $\tilde{y}(t)$ | Difference from reference |
| Circumflex | ^ | Estimation | $\hat{x}(t)$ | Based on current + past data |
| Circumflex | ^ | Prediction | $\hat{x}(t\|t-1)$ | Based on past data only |

: Variable processing notation {#tbl-variable-marks}

**Detailed Definitions**:

::: {#def-measurement}
## Measured Variable
$$
\bar{y}(t) = y(t) + v(t)
$$
where $v(t)$ is measurement noise.
:::

::: {#def-estimation}
## Estimated Variable
$$
\hat{x}(t) = \mathcal{E}\{x(t) \mid \bar{y}(0), \ldots, \bar{y}(t)\}
$$
Estimate based on measurements up to **current time** $t$.
:::

::: {#def-prediction}
## Predicted Variable
$$
\hat{x}(k+1\|k) = \mathcal{E}\{x(k+1) \mid \bar{y}(0), \ldots, \bar{y}(k)\}
$$
Prediction at time $k+1$ based on measurements up to **previous time** $k$.
:::

::: {#def-error}
## Prediction Error
$$
\tilde{x}(k) = x(k) - \hat{x}(k\|k-1)
$$
or more generally:
$$
\tilde{y}(k) = y(k) - y_{ref}(k)
$$
:::

### Stochastic Process Notation

::: {#def-psd}
## Power Spectral Density (PSD)

For a stationary stochastic process $d(t)$, the **power spectral density** is denoted:

$$
S_d^2(f) \geq 0 \quad [\text{units}^2/\text{Hz}]
$$

The **spectral density (SD)** is the square root:

$$
S_d(f) = \sqrt{S_d^2(f)} \quad [\text{units}/\sqrt{\text{Hz}}]
$$
:::

**Relationship to Autocorrelation**:
$$
S_d^2(f) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} R_d(\tau) e^{-j2\pi f\tau} d\tau
$$

where $R_d(\tau) = \mathcal{E}\{d(t)d(t+\tau)\}$ is the autocorrelation function.

: Notation for vectors and matrices {#tbl-vectors-matrices}

### Skew-Symmetric Matrix

For vector $\mathbf{v} = [v_1, v_2, v_3]^T$:

$$
[\mathbf{v}\times] = \mathbf{V}_\times = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & -v_3 & v_2 \\
v_3 & 0 & -v_1 \\
-v_2 & v_1 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
$$ {#eq-skew-symmetric-matrix}

**Properties**:
- $[\mathbf{v}\times]^T = -[\mathbf{v}\times]$ (skew-symmetric)
- $[\mathbf{v}\times]\mathbf{w} = \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{w}$ (cross product equivalence)
- $\det([\mathbf{v}\times]) = 0$ (singular)

| $\mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \mathbf{P})$ | Normal distribution | Multivariate Gaussian |
| $\mathbf{w}(k)$ | White noise sequence | $\mathcal{E}\{\mathbf{w}(k)\mathbf{w}(j)^T\} = \mathbf{Q}\delta_{kj}$ |
| $S_d(f)$ | Spectral density | $[\text{units}/\sqrt{\text{Hz}}]$ |
| $S_d^2(f)$ | Power spectral density | $[\text{units}^2/\text{Hz}]$ |
| $\bar{y}(t)$ | Measured variable | $\bar{y}(t) = y(t) + v(t)$ |
| $\hat{x}(t)$ | Estimated state | Current + past measurements |
| $\hat{x}(k\|k-1)$ | Predicted state | Past measurements only |
| $\tilde{x}(t)$ | Estimation/prediction error | $x(t) - \hat{x}(t)$ |
| $e_m(k)$ | Measured model error | $\bar{y}(k) - \hat{y}(k)$ |
| $G(s)$ | Transfer function (CT) | Laplace domain, $s = j\omega$ |
| $G(z)$ | Transfer function (DT) | z-domain |
| $S(s)$, $S(z)$ | Sensitivity function | $S = (I + GK)^{-1}$ |
| $T(s)$, $T(z)$ | Complementary sensitivity | $T = GK(I + GK)^{-1} = I - S$ |
| $\mathcal{H}_\infty$ | H-infinity norm | $\|G\|_\infty = \sup_\omega \bar{\sigma}(G(j\omega))$ |
| $\mathcal{H}_2$ | H-2 norm | Related to variance |

### Additional Definitions

::: {#def-white-noise}
## Discrete White Noise

A sequence $\{\mathbf{w}(k)\}$ is **white noise** if:

1. $\mathcal{E}\{\mathbf{w}(k)\} = \mathbf{0}$ (zero mean)
2. $\mathcal{E}\{\mathbf{w}(k)\mathbf{w}(j)^T\} = \mathbf{Q}\delta_{kj}$ (uncorrelated)

where $\delta_{kj}$ is the Kronecker delta.
:::

::: {#def-sensitivity}
## Sensitivity Functions

For a feedback system with plant $G$ and controller $K$:

**Sensitivity** (error to disturbance):
$$S = (I + GK)^{-1}$$

**Complementary Sensitivity** (output to reference):
$$T = GK(I + GK)^{-1} = I - S$$

**Identity relationship**:
$$S + T = I$$
:::

### Attitude Representations

| Symbol | Representation | Parameters | Range |
|--------|----------------|------------|-------|
| $\mathbf{R} \in SO(3)$ | Direction Cosine Matrix | 9 (6 constraints) | - |
| $(\phi, \theta, \psi)$ | Euler angles (3-2-1) | 3 | Singularity at $\theta = \pm 90°$ |
| $\mathbf{q} = [q_0, \mathbf{q}_v]$ | Quaternion | 4 (1 constraint) | $\|\mathbf{q}\| = 1$ |
| $\boldsymbol{\sigma}$ | Modified Rodrigues Parameters | 3 | Singularity at 360° |
| $(\phi, \mathbf{e})$ | Axis-angle | 4 (1 constraint) | $\phi \in [0, \pi]$, $\|\mathbf{e}\| = 1$ |

: Attitude representation comparison {#tbl-attitude-representations}

### Angular Velocity

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}_{b/i} = [\omega_x, \omega_y, \omega_z]^T
$$

Subscript notation $b/i$ means: "body frame relative to inertial frame"

### Orbital Elements

**Classical Orbital Elements (COE)**:

| Symbol | Element | Description |
|--------|---------|-------------|
| $a$ | Semi-major axis | Orbit size |
| $e$ | Eccentricity | Orbit shape |
| $i$ | Inclination | Orbit plane angle |
| $\Omega$ | RAAN | Right Ascension of Ascending Node |
| $\omega$ | Argument of periapsis | Orientation in plane |
| $\nu$ | True anomaly | Position in orbit |

: Classical orbital elements {#tbl-coe}

## Time Notation {#sec-time-notation}

- **Continuous time**: $t \in \mathbb{R}$, differential equations use $\dot{x}(t) = dx/dt$
- **Discrete time**: $k \in \mathbb{Z}$, difference equations use $x(k+1)$
- **Sampling period**: $T_s$ or $\Delta t$
- **Conversion**: $x(k) = x(kT_s)$

## Physical Units {#sec-units}

Standard SI units are used throughout unless otherwise specified:

| Quantity | Unit | Symbol |
|----------|------|--------|
| Length | meter | m |
| Mass | kilogram | kg |
| Time | second | s |
| Angle | radian | rad |
| Angular velocity | radians per second | rad/s |
| Force | newton | N |
| Torque | newton-meter | N·m |
| Moment of inertia | kilogram-meter squared | kg·m² |

: Standard physical units {#tbl-units}
